text: Gardner Remembers: The Lost Tapes an interview with Creole Myers (PLUS: Memphis musicologist, Linda Israels mini-biography of the man, The Growth and Death of Buddy Gardner Corey Mesler.
Name: Book 5

Name: Book 5

text: In thinking about the past, its important to decide how noisy it was.
Name: Book 5

text: she needs a shot of a very bored God.
Name: Book 5

text: The Growth and Death of Buddy Gardner by Dana Illsire  1975.
Name: Book 5

text: You know Buddy Slipshod Gardner from his later solo work, the early seventies stuff when he latched onto the singer/songwriter craze begun probably by Sweet Baby James.
Name: Book 5

text: You know him for his albums Rain and Other Distractions or I Was a Child When Smaller.
Name: Book 5

text: But this is the story of headier days, days when the Overton Park Shell was a magical place, the later rainbow implied.
Name: Book 5

text: When Buddy played lead guitar and sang for Black Lung, a blues rock band with a loyal Memphis following.
Name: Book 5

text: The late Lee Baker, a guitar god himself then, said about Buddy, He was the best of us.
Name: Book 5

text: He was a seer, a prophet.
Name: Book 5

text: That later acoustic stuff is crap, of course, but with Black Lung, Buddy was tapped into something other.
Name: Book 5

text: Back then, Black Lung played the Shell regularly, maybe opening for Johnny Winter, or teaming up with Mudboy and The Expanding Head Band for a mini-festival that would start at dusk and stumble into the early morning hours like a dreamer looking for paradise.
Name: Book 5

text: Lot of medicine passed about in those days.
Name: Book 5

text: Lot of prescriptions from the hoodoo man.
Name: Book 5

text: It was the sixties, people, and in Memphis that meant The Strip, The Shell, The Bitter Lemon.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy was known all those places.
Name: Book 5

text: Hell, Buddy was known everywhere in the River City.
Name: Book 5

text: This is the story of Buddys taint, the story of Buddy and his pact with the devil.
Name: Book 5

text: But Buddy had in him a black spot, fed by his desire to make it big, fed by ambition and greed and the sort of misdirected thinking which took Rolling Stone from the hands of the movement and placed it in the hands of the oppressors.
Name: Book 5

text: The commodifying of the sixties, if you will, as embodied by the soul of Buddy Gardner.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy Slipshod Gardner, Memphis answer to Jerry Garcia, Memphis gift to the world, from integrity and precocity to sell-out.
Name: Book 5

text: So much is lost now, so little written down, so little recorded.
Name: Book 5

text: For those with the stamina to search it out, Black Lung made one album, released on the Pepper label, a little Memphis soul mixed in with their own acid-blues.
Name: Book 5

text: It was called Turntable Poison.
Name: Book 5

text: Some say it sounded like The Rascals crossed with Hot Tuna.
Name: Book 5

text: One cut comes to mind, a piece they played in every set at The Shell, the ballad, Mr.
Name: Book 5

text: Handy and Hakel-Brend.
Name: Book 5

text: On the LP they insisted on the extended version with Buddys long, side-handed solos, slick as molten lead and the twelve minute drum solo by Skippy Quetzalcoatl, effectively killing the albums potential sales but insuring the group a spot in infamy alongside the lost tapes of Mudboy and the Neutrons and the missing five hours of von Stroheims Greed.
Name: Book 5

text: There was also the shorter, Blues for Wendy Ward, with its plaintive chorus, Thank you for at least that sweet ache, a phrase Buddy made sound like a supplication to the gods.
Name: Book 5

text: Wendy Ward got some air play around the country, on the late night FM stations, a minor flickering fame which only whet Buddys appetite for more, for larger radio audiences, larger followings, more groupies, better food backstage.
Name: Book 5

text: He wanted it all, Buddy did.
Name: Book 5

text: No one asked him, What is all.
Name: Book 5

text: If they had he might be here today.
Name: Book 5

text: Jim, Abbie, sweet Timmy Hardin.
Name: Book 5

text: Was it the same spirit in the night that whisked away all these mortal souls.
Name: Book 5

text: I only tell stories.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy got his first musicmaker, a ukulele, when he was a sapling, six years old, a first-grader at Idlewild Elementary.
Name: Book 5

text: He hung onto that uke as if it was his lifeline, time and time again having it taken from him on the playground where he would serenade a few curious classmates with his bewailing renditions of old Hank Williams songs.
Name: Book 5

text: The end of most schooldays found little Buddy in the principals office explaining why he should get his instrument back and vowing never to bring it again.
Name: Book 5

text: At twelve Buddy had graduated to electric guitar, a gift from his father, Al Gardner, who had played clarinet with a dance band called Dick Delisi and the Syncopators, at the Vapors Supper Club in his own mis-spent youth.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddys mother, Elise, could only pull at her hair and clap dishpan hands over her ears when the noise emanating from Buddys room began.
Name: Book 5

text: To her it sounded like the can-opener on warp speed.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy drew from everywhere, listening with equal fervor to Woody Guthrie, Odetta, Hoagy Carmichael, Django Reinhardt, Coleman Hawkins, Bill Haley, Lonnie Donegan, Howlin Wolf, Eric Dolphy, Skip James, Shostakovich.
Name: Book 5

text: Music fed Buddy the way most of us grew up on oatmeal and peanut butter.
Name: Book 5

text: And he absorbed it all, filtering it through his sensitive system to come out his delicate fingertips as liquid electricity, a sound even today many guitarists cannot duplicate and few can even explain.
Name: Book 5

text: By thirteen he had his own band, made up of less-skilled classmates at Snowden Elementary.
Name: Book 5

text: They called themselves Regulation Footwear and soon were playing gigs at high school dances and other social occasions, at Clearpool, even at an end-of-school year rally at the Overton Park Shell, foreshadowing later triumphs.
Name: Book 5

text: Clearly, it was Buddy people came to see, Buddy who garnered them engagements with older audiences.
Name: Book 5

text: Regulations drummer, poor Gyp Leach, could barely keep time on his Sears drumset, taking lessons after school at Guitar & Drum City, just progressing past a four-four beat.
Name: Book 5

text: But word was spreading about this precocious guitarist who sounded like a coup de foudre, this scrawny, pimply 8th grader with licks like a junkyard dog.
Name: Book 5

text: It was Jim Dickinson who dubbed Buddy Slipshod, not because Buddy was a sloppy player but because he put together such sloppy groups around him.
Name: Book 5

text: It mattered not to Buddy who was playing behind him.
Name: Book 5

text: He was lost in the ether, playing for his own private gods, letting the Lydian reverberation carry him away, the sound coming from his own self, you see.
Name: Book 5

text: Oh, of course, he knew when the bassist was faking it, or the drummer tripping over himself to keep up, or the rhythm guitarist playing the same three chords over and over, hoping his stroking would be lost in the thunder.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy knew it, but he didnt care.
Name: Book 5

text: He was making music, Memphis music, as sacred a calling as one could imagine.
Name: Book 5

text: Eventually, Buddy found his grounding, a group almost as flexuous and capable as Buddy, though few could approach Buddys genius for the ineffable, that secret other place he could go with his music.
Name: Book 5

text: Black Lung was born in the mid-sixties in an abandoned gas station when a bass player named Crafty Connor was introduced to Buddy through the coagulant Sid Selvidge.
Name: Book 5

text: Memphis music bred Memphis music, is how Sid describes it today.
Name: Book 5

text: Crafty, who had a face like moits in wool, attended East High where he had picked up the bass guitar (and put down his flugel horn much to his parents disfavor) when he first heard Jack Bruce play.
Name: Book 5

text: He wanted to be part of a power trio.
Name: Book 5

text: He wanted to be part of the best power trio Memphis could build and he wanted to build it.
Name: Book 5

text: He called Sid who said, Well, you could do a lot worse than hooking up with this young guitar kraken, Buddy Gardner.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy called Skippy Quetzalcoatl, who had a drumming lineage like no one elses.
Name: Book 5

text: His father had been a drummer and his father before him and back and back.
Name: Book 5

text: Beale Street whispers the name Quetzalcoatl, late nights when the horns have died down and the wind sloughs around shop corners and up alleyways.
Name: Book 5

text: It whispers the name like a mojo, a bit of song never transcribed, a bit of the old magic.
Name: Book 5

text: The abandoned gas station stood on a corner in midtown Memphis like a sepulcher, but it was soon to be transmogrified into a holy place, a place where anything could happen so beware.
Name: Book 5

text: A place as bright as Sun, as holy as Stax.
Name: Book 5

text: It is where Black Lung was born.
Name: Book 5

text: Today it is a Taco Bell.
Name: Book 5

text: Some still pass it by and cross themselves, hearken back to the days of divination, the days when music could save a dying nation, a nation bent on its own self-immolation.
Name: Book 5

text: That was the sixties.
Name: Book 5

text: Even in Memphis, an outpost planet.
Name: Book 5

text: A tributary, if you will.
Name: Book 5

text: That first session, so it is told, was as if energy itself had been created in that concrete empty shell, where grass pushed through the floor, straining to catch these new vibes, this new electrical Jubal.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy cut loose as if he had been formerly playing in a straightjacket.
Name: Book 5

text: And Skippy and Craftylater re-christened Castor and Polluxcreated a bottom like a sheol torture chamber, like Thor and Loki at war.
Name: Book 5

text: The crash and thunder coming out of that old Sinclair station was music from the beginning of time, the music the apes heard which made them men.
Name: Book 5

text: They cohered, they veered away and came back, like the trajectory of stars.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddys solos were like fluid silver; he was re-inventing the electric guitar.
Name: Book 5

text: It was around this time that Buddy began writing songs.
Name: Book 5

text: He was shy about it.
Name: Book 5

text: No one knows how many he wrote before he brought the first one to the group, the one that would later be their most requested song, I Love my Aunt Jemima.
Name: Book 5

text: Soon, though, he was bringing in songs in coacervations, as if he had eons of them bubbling up.
Name: Book 5

text: That first acceptance by the group opened the floodgates and Buddy Gardner became something of a songwriting machine.
Name: Book 5

text: Other artists recorded many of his best things, a blessing, and he became a regular at Hi Studios, at Sun and later at Ardent.
Name: Book 5

text: He was covered by many of the Mid-Souths biggest stars.
Name: Book 5

text: And later by some of the countrys:  Elvis Costello did Lemmy Cautions Incubus.
Name: Book 5

text: Van Morrison made Blues for Sid and Shirley a staple of his live performances.
Name: Book 5

text: Led Zeppelin, for Gods sake, did Procap All Night, Jimmy Page being an early fan, as is written.
Name: Book 5

text: Just for the record Buddy wrote these hits for other stars:  Buttermilk Thighs, Blues for Sandra Leathers, Wrong for the Right of Way, Arcade Late-Night Blues, Open Channel D, The Sins of Monk Cassava, They Bribe the Lazy Quadling, Patience Hell, Im Gonna Kill Something, The Nice and the Good, Strawberry Fields for Only a Little While, Take me for Granted, Please, Surfing the Big Muddy, The Rules for Hide and Seek, Young Avenue Blues, Picnic in Overton Park, Chin-Chin in Eden, Turn on Your Love Lights but Turn that Damn Stereo Down, and on and on.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy and the boys were off and running.
Name: Book 5

text: Soon they were one of the most sought after acts, playing gigs everywhere the area offered, in clubs, at outdoor festivals (happenings), and, of course, their famous half-aborted rooftop gig on top of the Sterick Building downtown.
Name: Book 5

text: Officer Mike Mooncalf Milton, one of the arresting officers, recalls to this day how polite Buddy and the band were as they were being ushered into police cars while the mob roared.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy Gardner was a gentleman in a jerk business, Officer Milton remembers.
Name: Book 5

text: This mildness, this Southern gentleman perception, follows Buddy to this day.
Name: Book 5

text: Its hard to find someone to speak ill of him, even those he later abandoned or stepped on on his way to the top.
Name: Book 5

text: He is often compared to courtly though dipsomaniacal photographer Bill Eggleston, a friend of Buddys from those acme days.
Name: Book 5

text: The cover photograph of Black Lungs Pepper Records album, Turntable Poison, is an unaccredited Eggleston photograph.
Name: Book 5

text: (It is, of course, a weathered Sinclair sign, imbued with the enchantment Mr.
Name: Book 5

text: Eggleston brought to all his work, a divergence quite inexplicable.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy was loved, revered.
Name: Book 5

text: He was not held to the same rules as everyone else.
Name: Book 5

text: So it goes with the great.
Name: Book 5

text: And when Buddy started using drugs, mixing bennies, reds and laxatives in dangerous quantities, no one was there to question him.
Name: Book 5

text: Of course, drugs were part of the scene then.
Name: Book 5

text: In the back of every minibus, in the bathroom of every nightclub, at practice sessions, in the homes of every groupie.
Name: Book 5

text: And Buddy had his groupies.
Name: Book 5

text: The twins used to joke that Buddy played for scrimption and blow jobs.
Name: Book 5

text: This has some truth to itthe money wasnt great in those days, asking for more money seen as bourgeois or worsebut the women were wonderful.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy, though, let it be said, played for one pure reason in those halcyon days.
Name: Book 5

text: He played for the rush, for the approach to the godhead.
Name: Book 5

text: It was religion to Buddy.
Name: Book 5

text: He sought the perfect note, the one that would bring about rapture.
Name: Book 5

text: One night, after a triple billing at the Shell (Black Lung was the middle act that night, sandwiched between the lesser talents of Rubdown and Barry and the White Panthers), Buddy wandered backstage after his set, still in that trance he seemed to enter when he played, and was greeted by a statuesque blond with eyes the color of the Wolf River at Sunset.
Name: Book 5

text: She stepped into his path like a gunfighter.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy looked deeply into her.
Name: Book 5

text: She was an equation he could not quite decipher.
Name: Book 5

text: Her eyes stayed on his.
Name: Book 5

text: She was bewitching him and even Buddy, already high from making music, was not immune.
Name: Book 5

text: Today people still talk about Lorelei Enos with a wary reticence.
Name: Book 5

text: Not much is known about her, you hear people say.
Name: Book 5

text: She came in on a bad wind and left on another, one roadie told me.
Name: Book 5

text: Lori was beautiful, a beautiful person, a beautiful body, but she was half siren.
Name: Book 5

text: She couldnt help it, another groupie remembers.
Name: Book 5

text: She was Satans mistress, a musician, who wishes to remain anonymous, summed her up.
Name: Book 5

text: That first night Buddy went home with her.
Name: Book 5

text: What happened there is shrouded in mystery, except Skippy recalls Buddy saying, She had the most beautiful sex Ive ever seen.
Name: Book 5

text: It tasted like mushrooms and ginger ale.
Name: Book 5

text: And its musk stayed on me for days, like it had gone subcutaneous, like it had replaced my own body odor.
Name: Book 5

text: Perhaps this was her hex: Ruthah: The perfume of Immortality.
Name: Book 5

text: Others talk about the size and welcoming essence of Loreleis breasts.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy was mothered; he fed there like a suckling, like a child.
Name: Book 5

text: It wasnt love but it was something between the sacred and the profane.
Name: Book 5

text: Some say Lorelei was responsible for the beginning of the slide downward for Buddy, filling his head with ideas of stardom, of leaving the backwash of Memphis and making it in a real town like L.
Name: Book 5

text: or Boston.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy listened to Lorelei, we know that, for better or worse.
Name: Book 5

text: Lets hearken back to a happier image.
Name: Book 5

text: A small recording studio.
Name: Book 5

text: A three-piece band, occasionally four when Jim Dickinson stops by and plays a little keyboards.
Name: Book 5

text: A 20X20 room covered in egg-cartons.
Name: Book 5

text: The preternatural silence beforehand.
Name: Book 5

text: The creation of something new.
Name: Book 5

text: From where there was nothing something now exists: songs, recordings, an album.
Name: Book 5

text: The making of Turntable Poison was a liminal time, a time of congruity, or grand passion.
Name: Book 5

text: The melding of the three (sometimes four) musicians was a Synchronicity.
Name: Book 5

text: It can happen more than once but it happened at least once for Black Lung.
Name: Book 5

text: Its there on that vinyl circle, waiting for the needle like a junkie.
Name: Book 5

text: And for anyone lucky enough to find that masterpiece in someones garage sale, in some second-hand record shop (where I hear it can go for upwards of a hundred dollars or more), at some friends apartment, there is knowledge passed.
Name: Book 5

text: Because anyone who hears Turntable Poison hears right away what could have been, what should have been.
Name: Book 5

text: It tears down ceiling tiles.
Name: Book 5

text: It disrupts fish in their blue aquarium lives.
Name: Book 5

text: It calls like a squonk in the wee hours, in the time between sleep and dawn.
Name: Book 5

text: It disrupts phone lines, calls old girlfriends and makes them want you again.
Name: Book 5

text: It stirs mud and makes bouillabaisse.
Name: Book 5

text: Black Lung fashioned alchemy, friends, at least once, in that small studio, over a period of 72 straight hours without sleep, so the story goes.
Name: Book 5

text: They laid down 43 minutes of catalytic reverb love.
Name: Book 5

text: Some of you understand.
Name: Book 5

text: (And, an aside: they did not feel it necessary to include that one song on the LP by the drummer.
Name: Book 5

text: An uncommon display of wisdom for the times but a good thing.
Name: Book 5

text: Skippy could no more sing or write a song than fly.
Name: Book 5

text: Listen to Blues for Wendy Ward.
Name: Book 5

text: Listen to In Real Time Nothing Happens.
Name: Book 5

text: Listen to A Marriage of Rue or Hayley Mills Underpants.
Name: Book 5

text: Under the surface like a chthonic river.
Name: Book 5

text: The only kind of magic that matters.
Name: Book 5

text: So, why would Buddy turn his back on the band after that triumph.
Name: Book 5

text: There are as many theories as theorists.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy wanted success, bigger success.
Name: Book 5

text: He tasted perfection with Turntable Poison but it was local perfection.
Name: Book 5

text: The album, though notorious today, an insiders treasure trove, a collectors grail, did not sell outside of Memphis.
Name: Book 5

text: No major label bought the rights to it.
Name: Book 5

text: Still, even this late, one wishes, with the advent of the compact disc revolution, that it would be reissued.
Name: Book 5

text: But now, Buddy wanted to be Hendrix, Clapton, Erik Brann, Zappa.
Name: Book 5

text: That he settled for being Livingston Taylor is the storys twist, what gives it verisimilitude.
Name: Book 5

text: Life is unpredictable, like a chemistry experiment.
Name: Book 5

text: Skippy and Crafty were not even angry with Buddy, to hear them tell it today.
Name: Book 5

text: Skippy works at Ardent and Crafty is a driver for UPS, but they recall those grand days with Buddy with something like ardor.
Name: Book 5

text: He was way ahead of all of us, Skippy says.
Name: Book 5

text: His energy came from someplace else.
Name: Book 5

text: At any rate in early 1970, having witnessed the death of some of the gods, Buddy Gardner turned his back on Memphis, moved to L.
Name: Book 5

text: with Lorelei, who then just as suddenly disappeared.
Name: Book 5

text: Like a genii whose work is done.
Name: Book 5

text: Some say she turned to making porno films.
Name: Book 5

text: Some say she works in television.
Name: Book 5

text: Some say she went back to perdition from whence she came.
Name: Book 5

text: But it was in L.
Name: Book 5

text: that Buddy transformed himself into a folk artist, a singer/songwriter with a heart on his sleeve and an ace up it.
Name: Book 5

text: He was as mellow as yellow, as smooth as California sunshine.
Name: Book 5

text: And as empty as a birds nest in December.
Name: Book 5

text: His two albums, I Was a Child When Smaller, and Rain and other Distractions, were mega-sellers.
Name: Book 5

text: He made it big.
Name: Book 5

text: For a price, yes.
Name: Book 5

text: Those last songs, dripping with feigned self-pity, seem apocalyptic in retrospect.
Name: Book 5

text: Allison All Gone and Goodbye to the Shell especially appear to comment on Buddys desire to burn his bridges, leave his Memphis past behind, forget his roots.
Name: Book 5

text: And, of course, then theres Burn my Bridges and Forget my Roots off the second album.
Name: Book 5

text: Even Buddys skillful acoustic playing cant save those albums from their own wallowing, from their stooping to the lowest common denominator.
Name: Book 5

text: Of course they sold.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy played with Carole King, with the L.
Name: Book 5

text: Session, with Linda Rondstadt.
Name: Book 5

text: He was revered, honored (Grammy for Song for L.
Name: Book 5

text: Enos, 1971), patted on his self-satisfied back.
Name: Book 5

text: But it was all so vacuous.
Name: Book 5

text: And, what for a Memphis musician is worse, so soulless.
Name: Book 5

text: Buddy had gone to hell, many in Memphis thought, though no one said so.
Name: Book 5

text: There was, for a homegrown prodigy, still respect, pride, a sort of sweetly sad valediction.
Name: Book 5

text: When Buddy was buried in L.
Name: Book 5

text: that was the final blow.
Name: Book 5

text: His parents flew out for the interment but no one else from Memphis went.
Name: Book 5

text: And, Creole Myers, the interviewer, died just last year of cancer.

text: Let us hearken back, briefly, to those days when music was being made because it was important, because genius finds its own level, because people needed godhead, if thats not overstating it.

text: Before the drugs, the recriminations, the lawsuits, the doubting of the very fiber of what the 60s meant to Memphis, to these sweet souls herein, and to the world at large.

text: Let us reimagine it, if we can, in all its efflorescence.

text: In all its pied beauty.

text: And, that said, presciently, Death is only a way station, between West Memphis and the coast.

text: These interviews were done in three sessions in early 1973, in San Francisco, by Creole Myers, at Buddy Gardners home.
Name: Book 5

text: Lorelei Enos was in and out.
Name: Book 5

text: One of the startling revelations found in these tapes is that Lorelei was with Buddy until the end.
Name: Book 5

text: Rumors had her abandoning him after they had left Memphis for Los Angeles.
Name: Book 5

text: Stories circulated back home about her, unflattering stories all, about her working in the pornographic film industry, about her fixing Buddy that final fix, about her leaving him for a slick-talking Hollywood casting agent.
Name: Book 5

text: What is made clear here is her devotion to him and his to her.
Name: Book 5

text: In this way they resemble John Lennon and Yoko Ono, another vastly misunderstood couple.

text: The tapes are in remarkably good shape, with only a few elisions, a few minutes of silence.

text: Buddy Gardner, when I knew him was a sweet, soft-spoken man, a man driven by ambition, sure, but, underneath that, there was a humility and a human heart.
Name: Book 5

text: Its all here in these tapes, so enough said.
Name: Book 5

text: Three weeks after these interviews were concluded, Buddy Gardner was found dead in his home, with a needle in his arm.
Name: Book 5

text: These tapes somehow also disappeared until 1999, when they were found in a stockroom in an abandoned studio in Los Angeles by a technician there who, with some heaven-sent Extra Sensitive Perception, sent them to Camel Jeremy Eros, c/o City Lights Bookstore, where for a while I was taking my mail, while recovering from a broken relationship, one that emasculated me, silenced me, did me up a treat.
Name: Book 5

text: These tapes were a godsendthey took me out of myself, out of the self-pity I was wallowing in.
Name: Book 5

text: Many thanks to John Wender, editor extraordinaire, who recognized what we had here and ran them in his celebrated periodical.
Name: Book 5

text: Hence, they ran first, almost in the form represented here, in three installments in Big City Magazine.

text: Buddy Gardner died young, tragically, just weeks after these interviews were concluded.

text: It lends a poignancy to what follows here, but is not the only reason to read, of course.

text: There is Buddys stature as one of the truly original artists of his time.

text: There is his infamous love affair with Lorelei who many blame for his death, like poor Ted Hughes and Sylvia Plath.

text: And there is the music, discussed here for the first time, how it was made, why it was made, for whom it was made.

text: Buddy is caught at a crucial moment, when he had left his psychedelic/blues/rock behind for California living and worldwide acclaim.

text: And he has been caught, naked, funny, combative, contradictive, hopeful, full of possibility, honest, bitter, loving, and, finally, with his brilliance still intact, after many had written him off.

text: All these memories collide in my head to form a capharnaum around what I want to know more concretely: how did Bob Dylan become important to me.
Name: Book 5

text: And the process must have been gradual, an accretion, Bob Dylan never became, for me, what James Joyce was for Richard Ellmann, or to use a less pretentious comparison, what hamburgers were for Wimpy.

text: At some point, at some fulcrum point, I understood.

text: Today, Bob Dylan remains a force in my life, though now, hes also a pal.
Name: Book 5

text: And I can go to himto his songs--when I am blue, when I am feeling that the world is a place of malefaction and discommoded energy, when I am feeling that there is nothing to be said for the human race, and I can be readjusted.
Name: Book 5

text: How this happens, why this happens, is secondary to the fact that it does.
Name: Book 5

text: I can listen to Frankie Lee and Judas Priest or Visions of Johanna or On the Road Again or Clothesline Saga or Watching the River Flow and feel that there are angels within humankind.
Name: Book 5

text: I can feel that we are not all lost in the caliginous wastes of our hopelessly chaotic lives.

text: This is the seed Im seeking, the truth Im trying in my clumsy way to impart.

text: Man, I sound like Rolling Stone.

text: What I mean is that rock wouldnt have held its place if it hadnt shifted, if the words didnt start to mean something.

text: The town was Lewiston, New York, a carbuncle on the gritty side of gritty Niagara Falls, New York, the former honeymoon capital of the United States, a country which, like Niagara Falls in microcosm, had lately fallen into disrepair.

text: Now, Niagara Falls, Ontario, just over the national border, where my mother's incredibly large family hailed from, was bright and brisk and clean and gardeny, the shiny flipside of its American counterpart.

text: Ive seen the great falls frozen; Ive seen it turned off as if there were a giant tap.

text: Ive stood on a rocking boat deck beneath its monstrous incontestableness.

text: The Canadian side had the greener grass, we all knew, even as late at night, in our trundle beds, we felt the thrum in our veins of a power larger than kings, a warbling of just what the earth has in mind, though it stayed, of course, just beyond us.
Name: Book 5

text: I longed to be from the Canadian side; I longed to be Canadian.

text: I thought my mother's family was just about the most exotic thing I could imagine (and later in school I used her heritage as if it were some bizarre ethnic upbringing, as if one side of my family tree was hung with Hottentots, or Eskimos), and my Canuck uncles, who were all big, strapping, lumberjack men, who could hold seven or eight nieces and nephews on their backs, were the ideal of manhood with which I constantly compared my scrawny, allergic, weak wristed self (No upper body strength, my tennis coach would later tell me).
Name: Book 5

text: This was the beginning of prog rocksort of, it wasnt really time, yet--and these guys, they were out there, I mean, beautiful cats, and Henry Cow had that guy--Frithwhat was his name.

text: weird cat, and, well, they were all Moog Synths and Synclaviers and violins and even marimbas, and, hell, we were just this heavy guitar oriented trio, you know.

text: It was an odd marriage that didnt really work.

text: And I think the crowd was there to see us, because, you know, who the hell were these foreigners with their off-the-wall songs and instrumentation.

text: And even though a lot was tolerated back thenI mean, Jesus, everyone had to have their 15 minute drum soloevery fucking concert, every fucking groupthe crowd didnt warm to Gentle Giantwhich was (is) a really tight combo, playing some farout stuff.

text: I think later, they returned to Memphis and played the Coliseum in front of Tull,  and went down a lot better.

text: Anyway, we started hearing this, you blew them off the stage and shit like that.

text: We were playing these gigs, getting bigger, getting a rep.
Name: Book 5

text: This was the end of the sixties.
Name: Book 5

text: There was talk of a concert in upstate New York that was gonna blow everybody away.
Name: Book 5

text: And we had just signed on with Pete Holder, who was both lawyer and agent.
Name: Book 5

text: Well, Pete said, he thought he could get us in on this New York concert.
Name: Book 5

text: He was talking to Bill Graham, who was bringing in some new acts, one of which, I remember was Cocker, who nobody knew.
Name: Book 5

text: And Graham was kind of holding the proceedings hostage, making demands, etc.
Name: Book 5

text: And Lennon was going to play, they said, but Hoover, that bastard,  was keeping him out of the states, and, anyway there was all this legal maneuvering going on, and, somehow, it just never happened.

text: You know, if Black Lung had played Woodstock it would have been a different history, right.

text: Wed be talking about a different story right now.

text: So, we didnt do that.
Name: Book 5

text: And we didnt do Wattstax, either.
Name: Book 5

text: (laughs)  Its funny now, but, at the time, it seemed to sound some kind of death knell to us.
Name: Book 5

text: Or maybe just to me.
Name: Book 5

text: I felt marginalized, like we were from this backwater town and everything was happening elsewhere, like you know, how everybody in Memphis feels about New York, or it was San Francisco for a while.
Name: Book 5

text: Of course, its only in retrospect that you see what Memphis had, what we had going on there, right around the corner.
Name: Book 5

text: I mean, everybody wants to know if I know Elvis, you know.
Name: Book 5

text: Everybody asks me that, everybody even in the business.
Name: Book 5

text: Hes revered, and thats right, thats right.
Name: Book 5

text: But, I mean, even McCartney wanted to know if Id ever met Elvis once he heard I was from Memphis.
Name: Book 5

text: I wanted to say, man, Memphis is more than Elvis, as great as he was.
Name: Book 5

text: Of course, the truth is, I did meet him.
Name: Book 5

text: It was at a benefit show and it was backstage.
Name: Book 5

text: I was roadying for Ike Turnerbriefly, yeah, I did that.
Name: Book 5

text: Just to get in, you know.
Name: Book 5

text: I was, what, 16 or something.
Name: Book 5

text: And Elvis came backstageI think he was mostly staying in Hollywood, then, making all those execrable movies--and I was like right there next to him and he had just done this kickass set and the crowd was eating him like pep-pills.
Name: Book 5

text: And he sat down next to me and turned over and said, youre in Black Lung, right.
Name: Book 5

text: I mean, this guy was fucking huge but he knew his home stuff.
Name: Book 5

text: He knew what was going on.
Name: Book 5

text: I was impressedhell, I was blown away.
Name: Book 5

text: So, yeah, Ive got my Elvis story.
Name: Book 5

text: Im from Memphis, I met Elvis.
Name: Book 5

text: Its not much of a story, really is it.
Name: Book 5

text: I mean, I know people who know Elvis, right.
Name: Book 5

text: But, man, lemme tell you.
Name: Book 5

text: From where we were there was Ike and Isaac and Carla and that whole Stax group.
Name: Book 5

text: They were like the best thing wed ever seen or heard.
Name: Book 5

text: Just to have sat in with Cropper makes my whole career worth whileI mean it, man, Cropper and the Horns.
Name: Book 5

text: I played with them.
Name: Book 5

text: When they were at their peak, too.
Name: Book 5

text: Thats what I want people to ask me.
Name: Book 5

text: What about fucking Booker T.
Name: Book 5

text: Did you know him.
Name: Book 5

text: Did you ever get to sit in with the Hi Rhythm Section.
Name: Book 5

text: These are the questions I wanna answer.
Name: Book 5

text: So, like, I remember the whole Wattstax thingit was all so casual in Memphis.
Name: Book 5

text: It was like, you wanna go, you wanna play with us this weekend.
Name: Book 5

text: No one understood what it all was gonna mean.
Name: Book 5

text: How could they, right.
Name: Book 5

text: Of course, this was while it was spinning out of control for me.
Name: Book 5

text: Slowly spinning out of control, like I could chart it.
Name: Book 5

text: Like I could write it out on a graphthe Venn diagram of how to have a nervous breakdown.
Name: Book 5

text: And the sixties were winding down like a colorful toy that was starting to show its cracks and whose motor was creaky with rust.
Name: Book 5

text: Things were getting grim.
Name: Book 5

text: More and more people in the street but it didnt look like those fuckers in Washington were gonna do a damn thing differentthe war, shit, look at it, its just deeper and deeper shit.
Name: Book 5

text: And they were turning hoses on kids.
Name: Book 5

text: Chicago happened, Abbie was arrested and tried.
Name: Book 5

text: They tied a man to a chairthis was 1968, man, not 1868.
Name: Book 5

text: I was aghast, the whole country was aghast, I mean, those who cared.
Name: Book 5

text: It seemed the vultures had descended and taken over.
Name: Book 5

text: They were picking the bones of America, licking their slathering jaws and, well, it all was just so bleak bleak bleak.
Name: Book 5

text: When they shot the kids at Kent, I went into a tailspin.
Name: Book 5

text: I wish I had Neils presence of mindI mean, he picks up his guitar and writes, Tin soldiers and Nixon coming, man, and just put it all out there, naked, true.
Name: Book 5

text: It was like Lennon blasting us with Revolution.
Name: Book 5

text: And, man, I was just so out of it, I was just so fucking passive.
Name: Book 5

text: I was inert, man.
Name: Book 5

text: You gotta understand, I wanted to be on the front lines, but I was so far away, I was in fucking Nether World, you know.
Name: Book 5

text: Dylan asking, How does it feel to be on your own like a complete unknown.
Name: Book 5

text: and I kept thinking about that and I was one gone gommie.
Name: Book 5

text: I couldnt see myself in the mirror.
Name: Book 5

text: There was still hope but, damn, it was spinning too fast.
Name: Book 5

text: It seemed like every fucking day something was happening that you had to respond to, you know.
Name: Book 5

text: To not respond was to be dead, to be irrelevant.
Name: Book 5

text: Wont you please come to Chicago just to sing.
Name: Book 5

text: you know.
Name: Book 5

text: I thought, yeah, I could, I could.
Name: Book 5

text: But, in the end, I didnt, I didnt do a fucking thing.
Name: Book 5

text: I Salingered myself, dad, I put myself away for my own good.
Name: Book 5

text: And music, how did music get so tangled in with politics.
Name: Book 5

text: I dont knowbut suddenly it was like, hey, we matter, were a voice.
Name: Book 5

text: And, I dont knowwere we geared up for that.
Name: Book 5

text: I dont think so.
Name: Book 5

text: Then you know the worst thing happened.
Name: Book 5

text: CM: 	What was that.
Name: Book 5

text: BG: 	Well, Reverend King getting shot in Memphis.
Name: Book 5

text: CM: 	That was before Woodstock.
Name: Book 5

text: BG:  	I know, I know.
Name: Book 5

text: Im not making a timeline here, man, Im riffing on what went wrong, trying to tell you what it felt like.
Name: Book 5

text: There we were on the world stage suddenly.
Name: Book 5

text: And Memphis became the face of deadly racism.
Name: Book 5

text: It was all too much.
Name: Book 5

text: It was blowing my mind, I admit it.
Name: Book 5

text: I was feeling wrung out.
Name: Book 5

text: I had written Blues for Sandra Leathers, Open Channel D, Young Avenue Blues,  The Sins of Monk Cassava, Chin-Chin in Eden,  They Bribe the Lazy Quadling,  Take me for Granted, Please, Surfing the Big Muddy, If it Wasnt Televised, It didnt Happen, The Rules for Hide and Seek, Picnic in Overton Park, you know.
Name: Book 5

text: And it all seemed so paltry suddenly.
Name: Book 5

text: So outside of things.
Name: Book 5

text: Only Lor knows this.
Name: Book 5

text: I went into seclusion, I hid from the world, man.
Name: Book 5

text: And, really, I think, that was the end of Black Lung.
Name: Book 5

text: My black period, my darkest days.
Name: Book 5

text: Lor and I rented a cabin up on the White River and we just hid away.
Name: Book 5

text: I didnt write a fucking thing, didnt even read the newspapers.
Name: Book 5

text: I dont mean to imply that I could have done something, that I had any more power than the Pope or The Beatles or, you know, fucking McNamara.
Name: Book 5

text: I mean, though, that I wanted to know, I wanted to understand.
Name: Book 5

text: I wanted the information that Walter Cronkite or Eric Sevareid had, the insider stuff, so that I wasnt just up there entertaining the fuel for the fire, you know, like the orchestras that played as the Jews were led into the ovens.
Name: Book 5

text: I started to feel like that, that I was a chimp, a dancing fool.
Name: Book 5

text: This was like before The Moratorium, right.
Name: Book 5

text: Before we really all felt the power.
Name: Book 5

text: The War was just this endless one-note playing over and over and driving us insaneme insane, sorry, driving me insane.
Name: Book 5

text: And, like, I know that a song is just a songyet, I have to believe there is something there, an element, a catalytically charged element.
Name: Book 5

text: I didnt want religionwho listens to priests, clergymen, even those who take to the streets.
Name: Book 5

text: Ali has more power.
Name: Book 5

text: Ali reaches more people.
Name: Book 5

text: But a song, you know, a good song, well, it does tunnel deep into the consciousness.
Name: Book 5

text: Did I think I could do anything with the right words, well-placed, well-played.
Name: Book 5

text: No, I knew better.
Name: Book 5

text: But, I did thinkI do thinkthat we had to stand for something other than pop ditties, you dig.
Name: Book 5

text: The people who needed helpwell, it was all so fucking clear thenAIM and the draft dodgers and the blacks and, Jesus, I mean, if you couldnt see the problem you really were part of the problem.
Name: Book 5

text: So, seeing it, what does one do.
Name: Book 5

text: What could one do.
Name: Book 5

text: Power, in the end, is just another word, too, but the power is gonna belong to someone, so, in the end, who decides.
Name: Book 5

text: Who decides Nixon has more power than Mao, or John Lennon has more power than Roy Cohn.
Name: Book 5

text: I was wrestling with these things, absurd things, but I couldnt see clearly.
Name: Book 5

text: All I saw was blackness, the blackness of dried blood.
Name: Book 5

text: I dont know what Crafty and Skippy thoughtI didnt even leave them a note.
Name: Book 5

text: I feel bad about it nowand this, finally, I think, was what pissed Crafty off and led him to hire a lawyer for himself, to try and, you know, basically, steal my material.
Name: Book 5

text: It was like, if youre not gonna represent yourself well, were gonna take away your soul, all your work, all your history.
Name: Book 5

text: That shark he hired---what a bastard.
Name: Book 5

text: But, I was oblivious at the time.
Name: Book 5

text: He handled it all.
Name: Book 5

text: While I was gone.
Name: Book 5

text: Only he knew I was gone although we were incommunicado, no phone even.
Name: Book 5

text: I think I called him once from town and said something like, Dont tell me about any of the shit thats going down.
Name: Book 5

text: Dont tell me there are more kids dead at more universities.
Name: Book 5

text: Dont tell me about Nixon, Crafty or his reptilian lawyer.
Name: Book 5

text: Just send me my guitar.
Name: Book 5

text: I did--after a while I wanted it---get my guitar up there, up in my White River seclusion, but I only wanted it to serenade Lorelei.
Name: Book 5

text: I played on the porch of our cabin, didnt singcouldnt singjust strummed and hummed to her.
Name: Book 5

text: And, you know, we didnt wear any clothesthis was summer and it was beautiful out on that porchand we became known as the naked hippie coupleamong the other cabins spread out along the river.
Name: Book 5

text: Not that we talked to anyone, but they were aware of us, apparently.
Name: Book 5

text: And, of course, there were binoculars trained on Lor, as she walked around in the nude.
Name: Book 5

text: (laughs)  But, man, that was my only comfort, my woman, her body, her sweet, enveloping body.
Name: Book 5

text: She suckled me like I was a childshe has these breasts, well, sorryanyway, we did a lot of fucking, you know, the kind you do until you cry yourself to sleep.
Name: Book 5

text: We fucked in the cold water of the river which ran right below the cabin, standing up, man, cold as hell, I held her up and entered her right there, in front of God and everybody.
Name: Book 5

text: I was empty man, as empty as a skull.
Name: Book 5

text: And Lor brought me back.
Name: Book 5

text: Thats what saved me, moved me on down the road.

text: That lost time in Arkansas, that was the crux, the fulcrum that my life turned on.
Name: Book 5

Name: Book 5

text: I believe that, dad, I was reborn in that cabin.
Name: Book 5

text: I was reborn at my womans breast.
Name: Book 5

text: Can you dig that.
Name: Book 5

text: Probably not, right, I mean, its private and honored so, you cant dig, am I right.
Name: Book 5

text: CM: 	I follow you.
Name: Book 5

text: Ive had my dark days of the soul, too.
Name: Book 5

text: BG:  	Have you, Creole.
Name: Book 5

text: Lets talk about you.
Name: Book 5

text: CM: 	So, its ok to say that you had a complete nervous breakdown at this time.
Name: Book 5

text: Thats what it was.
Name: Book 5

text: I found myself with existential nausea, the kind you wake up with in the morning and its all over you like an animal and theres nowhere to go because the beast is you.
Name: Book 5

text: I often backed myself into a corner and curled there like a fetus, as if covering my balls and stomach were protection, as if I feared some attack of a physical nature.
Name: Book 5

text: This is what the fear does to you.
Name: Book 5

text: Its totally debilitating, man.
Name: Book 5

text: Nausea can unseat you, can defeat the strongest man.
Name: Book 5

text: And its a nausea that is in your bloodyour whole body is sick.
Name: Book 5

text: And, you know, looking at it now, I think I was sick like the country was sick.
Name: Book 5

text: I was nauseated for the USA, you dig.
Name: Book 5

text: I took those deaths, that ignominious war, the whole queasy zeitgeist of the times and internalized them.
Name: Book 5

text: And I couldnt get away, not in a cabin, not in my music, not anywhere, man, because the enemy was me.
Name: Book 5

text: And, dad, anyone whos ever had that kind of stomach failure, where you feel like your whole system is shutting down on you, knows how bone-deep that kind of pain and fear is.
Name: Book 5

text: This is when I started shooting horse.
Name: Book 5

text: Im not proud of it.
Name: Book 5

text: You know, Id always used drugs, to perform, to get up for a performance, to come down afterwardsthere were always pills around.
Name: Book 5

text: But I had stayed away from the hard stuff until my GI went bad.
Name: Book 5

text: I couldnt take itI admit it, I couldnt take it, man.
Name: Book 5

text: I started using heroin.
Name: Book 5

text: It was there for me and no one else was helping with the pain, and I thought, shit, man, Ill medicate myself.
Name: Book 5

text: Well, I wasnt clear enough to be thinking that concretely, but, you dig, I had to do something.
Name: Book 5

text: I was sneaking the shit, too.
Name: Book 5

text: Sneaking it behind Lors back, which is disgraceful, sad.
Name: Book 5

text: Hell, Im still sorry.
Name: Book 5

text: CM: 	But you got off the junk.
Name: Book 5

text: BG:  	I(garbled)yeah, I mean, yeah.
Name: Book 5

Name: Book 5

Name: Book 5

text: I mean, Lorelei reached down into the cosmic soup and pulled me out.
Name: Book 5

text: But I was still a mess, you know.
Name: Book 5

text: I was wrung out, without hope or talent or release.
Name: Book 5

text: I was limp, like a rope, see, like a rope that formerly held such tension, then snappedI was that rope.
Name: Book 5

text: I was weak as a bled calf.
Name: Book 5

Name: Book 5

text: BG: 	The funny farm, the sanitarium, the nut house, the 13th floor.
Name: Book 5

Name: Book 5

text: This is what I told the doctorsno wonder they kept me, right.
Name: Book 5

text: I mean, I got off that elevator on the 13th floorLor was literally holding me upand I freaked out just because of the number.
Name: Book 5

text: That was just the beginning of my wondrous captivity, my imprisonment in the tower.
Name: Book 5

text: I had to stay there until the angels came to get me.

text: CM:  	How long were you, um, kept.
Name: Book 5

text: BG:  	Shit, what was it, Lor.
Name: Book 5

text: Three weeks, a month.
Name: Book 5

text: LE: 	About 9 weeks, dear.
Name: Book 5

text: CM:  	What was the diagnosis.
Name: Book 5

text: BG:  	Well, I mean, shit, it was that I was crazy, right.
Name: Book 5

text: I thought I was carrying the countrys disease in me, this is what I said.
Name: Book 5

text: They called it a sort of God complex.
Name: Book 5

text: What was the word, dysphoria.
Name: Book 5

text: I was joylessI was beyond joy.
Name: Book 5

text: I think I presented them with a real interesting case, you know.
Name: Book 5

text: I mean, one of the doctors I know, a young guy, a pretty hip cat, he knew my stuff.
Name: Book 5

text: He wanted to talk about the music, nothing but the music.
Name: Book 5

text: I mean, he was disguising it as a mental exam, but it was mostly curiosity, you know, I was the closest thing to a celebrity hed ever treated.

text: We talked about The Highsteppers, Sam the Sham, I mean, he knew them all, all the old blues guys even.
Name: Book 5

text: I dont think he was speeding my recovery.
Name: Book 5

text: (laughs).
Name: Book 5

text: CM:  	Nine weeksthats a pretty long stay, isnt it.
Name: Book 5

text: This was in Memphis.
Name: Book 5

text: BG:  	Yeah, nine weeks, thats fairly serious to be locked up.
Name: Book 5

text: Well, sort of locked up.
Name: Book 5

text: I mean, I could have left.
Name: Book 5

text: There were no bars or anything.
Name: Book 5

text: But, I had no will, I had no good reason to do anything.
Name: Book 5

text: Lorelei would just sit with me and wed talk about small things, you know, what it was like outside, what she was reading, some painting she was doing.

text: Almost anything but me getting back to the music.
Name: Book 5

text: See, Lor, instinctively knew that was the sticking point, that me making music again was the key, but, also my deepest fearthat Id lost it all.

text: (laughs)  Its funny now.

text: COREY MESLER has published in numerous journals and anthologies.
Name: Book 5

text: He has authored four novels: Talk: A Novel in Dialogue (2002), We Are Billion-Year-Old Carbon (2006), The Ballad of the Two Tom Mores (2010), and Following Richard Brautigan (2010); two full-length poetry collections: Some Identity Problems (2008) and Before the Great Troubling (2011); and three books of short stories: Listen: 29 Short Conversations (2009), Notes Toward the Story and Other Stories (2011), and Ill Give You Something to Cry About (2011).
Name: Book 5

text: He has also published a dozen chapbooks of both poetry and prose.
Name: Book 5

text: He has been nominated for the Pushcart Prize numerous times, and two of his poems have been selected for Garrison Keillors Writers Almanac.
